msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Genesis 31
ab.l:
And Jacob heard the words of Laban’s sons, saying,
‘Jacob has taken away all that was our father’s, and he has made this fortune from that which was our father’s.’

And Jacob saw the countenance
of Laban, and, lo, it was not toward him as before.

And the Lord said to Jacob, ‘Return to the land of your fathers, and
to your kindred, and my help will be with you.

And
Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field
to his flock.

And he said to them, ‘I see
your father’s countenance, that it is not toward me as before.
And the God of my father has been with me.
And you know that with all my power I have served your father.

And your father has deceived me, and changed
my wages in ten ways, but God did not let him
hurt me.

If he said thus: “The speckled
shall be your wages,” then all the flock bore speckled.
And if he said thus: “The striped shall be your wages,”
then all the flock bore striped.

Thus
God has taken away the livestock of your father, and given them to me.

And it was at the time that the flock conceived, and I raised
my eyes, and saw in a dream: and, lo, the rams
which walked with the flock were striped, speckled, and
spotted.

And the angel of God said to me
in a dream, “Jacob,” and I said, “Lo, I am here.”

And he said, “Lift up now your eyes, and see, all
the rams which walk with the livestock are striped, speckled, and
spotted. Because I have seen everything that Laban is doing to you.

I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed
the pillar, and where you vowed a vow to me. Now arise,
go out from this land, and return to the land of your kindred.”’

And Rachel and Leah answered, and they said to him,
‘Is there still a portion or share for us in our father’s house?

Lo, were are thought of as strangers by him, because he has sold us,
and has devoured our silver as well.

Because all
the wealth that God has taken from our father: it is ours and our
children’s. And now, do everything that God has said to you.’

So Jacob rose up, and lifted his sons and
his wives and set them on camels.

And he drove away all his livestock, and
all his goods which he gained, the multitude of goods which he had gotten in Paddan-Aram,
to go to Isaac, his father, in the land of Canaan.

And
Laban went to shear his sheep. And Rachel stole
the household idols that were her father’s.

And
Jacob stole the heart of Laban, the Aramean, by not telling him
that he was fleeing.

And he fled with all that he had,
and he rose up, and crossed the river, and set his face
toward mount Gilead.

And it was told to Laban
on the third day that Jacob had fled.

And he took
his brothers with him, and pursued Jacob
seven days’ journey, and pursued and he reached him in Mount Gilead.

And an angel came to Laban, the Aramean, in a dream by night,
and said to him, ‘Take heed to yourself lest you speak with Jacob:
from good to bad.’

Then Laban reached
Jacob, and Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain. And Laban
with his brothers pitched his tent in the mount of Gilead.

And Laban said to Jacob, ‘What have you done, that you have stolen
my heart, and driven away my daughters like captives
of a sword?

Why did you hide to flee away, and
stole my heart, and did not tell me? And I would have sent you off
with mirth, and with songs, with a tambourine, and with a qobuz?

And have not left me time to kiss my sons
and my daughters? Now you’ve been foolish to do this.

It is in the power of my hand to do bad to you, but
the God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, “Take heed
to yourself lest you speak with Jacob: from good to bad.”

And now, you have gone away because you longed greatly
for your father’s house, but why did you steal my gods?’

And
Jacob answered and said to Laban, ‘I did not tell you
that I go because I was afraid, because I said, “Lest you rob your daughters from me.”

But I did not take your gods, anyone with whom you find your gods,
shall not live. In front of our brothers recognize what is
yours still with me, and take it to you.’ And Jacob did not know that
Rachel had stolen the household idols.

And Laban came in
Jacob’s tent, and in Leah’s tent, and in the two maidservants’ tents,
but he did not find them. And came out from Leah’s tent and came in
Rachel’s tent.

And Rachel had taken the household idols,
and put them in the camel’s saddle, and sat
on them. And Laban felt |around| the whole tent,
but he did not find them.

And she said to her father,
‘Let there be no anger in my lord’s eyes that I cannot rise up
before you, because I have the way of women.’ And he searched, but did not find
the household idols.

And Jacob was angry,
and he quarrelled with Laban. And started and said to Laban,
‘What is my trespass? What is my sin, that you have pursued me,

That you have felt through all my vessels? What did you find of all
your household vessels? Set it here, before my brothers
that are also your brothers, that they may judge
between us two.

These twenty years I have been with you.
Your ewes and your |female| goats have not miscarried,
and I have not eaten the rams of your flocks.

What was torn up |by wild beasts| I did not bring to you.
I would bear the punishment of it myself: you would require it from my hand,
whether stolen by day or stolen by night.

I was
the herdsman of your flock, the drought of sun burned me by day,
and the cold by night, and my sleep disturbed me and fled from my eyes.

These were for me twenty years in your house. I served
you fourteen years for your two daughters, and six years
for your flock, and you have changed my wages in ten ways.

If the help of the God of my father, the God
of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been on my side,
by now you would have sent me away empty. God saw my affliction and the labour
of my hands and rebuked you last night.’

And Laban answered and said to Jacob, ‘These daughters
are my daughters, and these children are my children, and these flocks are my flocks,
and all that you see is mine. But what can I do to my daughters, to these,
today, or to their children whom they have borne?

So now come, let us make a covenant, I and you. And let it be
for a witness between me and you.’

And Jacob took a stone,
and set it up for a pillar.

And Jacob said
to his brothers, ‘Gather stones,’ and they took stones and made
a heap. And they ate there at the heap.

And
Laban called it Jegar-Sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.

And Laban said, ‘This heap is a witness between me
and you this day.’ On account of this he called its name Galeed,

And Watchtower, because he said, ‘May the Lord watch between me and you
when we hide from one another.

If you shall afflict
my daughters, or if you shall take other wives beside my daughters, no
other man is with us, see, God is witness between me and you.’

And Laban said to Jacob, ‘Behold this heap,
and behold this pillar, which I have set between me and you.

This heap is a witness, and this pillar is a witness:
that I may not pass over this heap to you if I were hostile to you,
and, if you were hostile to me, that you may not pass over
this heap and over this pillar to me,
for bad.

The God of Abraham, and the God
of Nahor, Elohei the God of their father, judge between us.’ And
Jacob swore by the Fear of his father Isaac.

And Jacob offered sacrifice in the mountain, and called his brothers to eat
bread, and they ate bread, and spent the night in the mountain.

And early in the morning Laban rose up and kissed
his sons and his daughters and blessed them. And Laban departed and returned
to his place.

app.note: A mistranslation based on the consfusion of Heb. מִצְפָּה ‘Mizpah (a place in Gilead)’ and Heb. מִצְפֶּה ‘1. watchtower; 2. lookout’. Translated correctly in C, V, and R.
